thread.title: A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss
thread.title_full: A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss

author: Mac Cerullo
title: A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss
text:
Amanda Sabga A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Nicole Carzo leads her heat of the 100-yard butterfly during the team's dual meet against Acton-Boxboro. Andover went on to win the meet 108.5-75.5. Amanda Sabga A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Grace Alwan swims in the 100-yard backstroke during Thursday's 108.5-75.5 win over Acton-Boxboro. Amanda Sabga A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Julia Donahue swims in the 100-yard breaststroke during Thursday's swim meet against Acton-Boxboro. Amanda Sabga A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Andover's Mia Galat and Nika Sokolova cheer on their teammates during Thursday's swim meet against Acton-Boxboro. Amanda Sabga A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss 
AMANDA SABGA/Staff Photo Swimmers take off for the 200-yard freestyle relay during Andover's swim meet against Acton-Boxboro on Thursday. Posted: Friday, October 23, 2015 1:00 am A JOB WELL DONE: Andover swimming hands archrival Acton-Boxboro first loss Mac Cerullo Eagle-Tribune 
ANDOVER -- Normally, Andover swimming has the talent and the depth to blow teams out of the water, but going into Thursday’s showdown with unbeaten Acton-Boxboro, Marilyn Fitzgerald knew talent alone wouldn’t be enough. 
So on Wednesday night, the veteran Andover coach gathered her girls in their conference room and assembled a game plan that would have made Bill Belichick proud. 
“It was so intense,” said Andover senior quad-captain Nikole Rudis. “We had white boards full of times, who needs to go where, who needs to do what. Everyone had a job to do.” 
Fitzgerald went down the lineup, event by event, and assigned each swimmer an opponent to beat and the time they’d need to beat them. When the girls hit the pool on Thursday, they had a clear blueprint for success, but even Fitzgerald couldn’t have imagined her team would execute the plan to such perfection. 
Andover came flying out of the gate and never looked back, starting the meet off by taking first and second in the 200-yard medley relay and extending its lead from there. By the time it was over, Andover had placed first in nine of the 12 events to pick up the convincing 108.5-75.5 win. 
“It was so special,” said senior quad-captain Lizzy Troiano. “We really wanted this, so to all work together and get this, something we all really wanted, it was just so exciting.” 
Acton-Boxboro has been something of a white whale for Andover over the past few years. Since the current crop of seniors were freshmen, Andover has only lost two dual meets in the regular season, and both came against the Colonials. 
The first came in 2013, when Acton-Boxboro beat Andover 95-91 in a meet that came down to the final event. That loss also snapped a 55-meet win streak that dated back to the 2008 regular season finale. 
Then last year, the Colonials beat Andover again 98-88, a loss the Warrior swimmers vowed to learn from. 
“The mindset coming out was what can we do to make ourselves better,” Rudis said. “What can we do to make our team better, what can we do as people to get ourselves up, pick ourselves up and come back guns blazing.” 
Andover went on to win that year’s state championship, edging out Acton-Boxboro along the way, and this week when the girls had a chance to face their rivals head on, they pulled out all the stops. 
After Wednesday’s team meeting was over, the girls gathered for their traditional pre-meet pasta dinner. Then, on Thursday morning, they all came to school dressed in army gear, which they then wore to the pool, making sure the Colonial girls could see. 
“We always do Army Day against them,” said senior Nicole Carzo. “We dress up like we’re going to war.” 
Finally, right before the meet began, the girls gathered in a circle at the end of the pool for their pre-swim ritual, a haka-like chant that starts with “We Will Rock You” before evolving into an incomprehensible wall of noise echoing through the building. 
With that, the Warriors got to work, and from the seniors to the freshmen, everyone did their job. 
“This year I feel like the bar has been raised higher,” Fitzgerald said. “Hearing the noise level, seeing the way this team comes together, they’ve bought into this, they’ve totally bought in to what happens on the team.” Sign Up / Sign In With your existing account from... {* loginWidget *}
